I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
of up to $103 million to Rajasthan Sun Technique Energy Private Limited (RSTEPL) for the 
Rajasthan Concentrating Solar Power Project in India. 
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
A.  Project Identification and Description 
1.  Project Identification 
2.  Launched in January 2010, the Jawaharlal Nehru National Solar Mission (NSM) is an 
initiative of the Government of India to promote solar power development in India. The NSM 
envisages installed solar power generation capacity of 2 gigawatts (GW) by 2013, 10 GW by 
2017, and 20 GW by 2022. Through such projects, the NSM also envisages the development of 
a diversified manufacturing base in India of solar power components for the region. Under 
phase 1 of the NSM (2010–2013), NTPC Vidyut Vyapar Nigam Limited (NVVN)—the nodal 
agency under the NSM for the procurement of solar power—invited bids for the development of 
470 megawatts (MW) of concentrating solar power (CSP) and 150 MW of solar photovoltaic 
capacity. Of the 60 companies that participated in the bid process for the CSP projects, seven 
were  selected  on  the  basis  of  the  discount  offered  to  the  Central  Electricity  Regulatory 
Commission feed-in tariff for CSP projects. One of the successful bidders was RSTEPL, a 100% 
subsidiary of Reliance Power Limited (RPL). 
 
3.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) was approached by RPL in October 2011 in regard 
to financing for the project. From initial discussions between RPL and ADB, ADB viewed that 
the project possessed sound fundamentals, including the financial strength of the sponsor, high-
quality project preparatory work, potential benefits for local manufacturing of solar components, 
and  a  strong  technology  partner.  The  project  is  the  largest  among  the  37  projects  being 
developed under phase 1 of the NSM. The assistance to the project will demonstrate strong 
support for the government’s NSM as well as for the further development of solar energy in the 
underdeveloped  state  of  Rajasthan.  The  project  will  strongly  complement  ADB’s  ongoing 
initiatives in solar energy in India, including technical assistance to the nodal ministry for the 
NSM, regular training programs on solar energy for financial institutions, and the $150 million 
solar power generation guarantee facility supporting smaller solar power projects.1 This will be 
ADB’s first financing of a CSP project. 
 
2.  Project Design 
4.  The project entails the construction of a 100 MW CSP generation plant near the village 
of Dhursar in Jaisalmer district of Rajasthan state. The project site is 180 kilometers (km) west 
of the city of Jodhpur and 10 km from the Jodhpur–Jaisalmer national highway (NH-114). The 
annual direct normal irradiance2 at the project site is estimated to be 2,071 kilowatt-hours per 
square meter, one of the highest in the country. 
 
                                                 
1  ADB. 2011. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Guarantee Facility 
for Solar Power Generation in India. Manila (April). 
2  Direct normal irradiance is the amount of solar radiation received per unit area by a surface that is always held 
perpendicular to the rays that come in a straight line from the direction of the sun at its current position in the sky, 
excluding solar radiation that is scattered or reflected by atmospheric components in the sky.

2  
5.  The project will use compact linear fresnel reflector (CLFR) technology to capture solar 
energy  and  convert  water  to  superheated  steam  through  multiple  solar  steam  generators 
(SSGs). The steam produced will be used to drive a steam turbine which will produce electricity. 
Sunlight is reflected onto the linear SSGs by a series of flat reflectors or mirrors arranged in 
parallel rows. Based on the sun’s exact position at any given time of the day, the position of the 
mirrors is adjusted through drive motors to reflect the sunlight onto a series of tubes that run the 
length of the SSGs. Water in the tubes is heated by the sun’s rays up to 400° Celsius and 
converted into saturated and superheated steam. The project consists of approximately 39 
SSGs each producing steam independently. Steam leaving the SSG tubes is collected in a 
piping system and transported to the steam turbine. 
 
6.  The electricity generated from the project will be evacuated from the project site to the 
existing 220-kilovolt (kV) Dechu substation of Rajasthan Vidyut Prasaran Nigam Limited, the 
state transmission company, through a 30-km 220-kV double circuit transmission line. The 
transmission line is currently under construction by Dahanu Solar Power Private Limited for a 40 
MW solar photovoltaic plant adjacent to the project site. 
 
3.  The Borrower and Sponsor 
7.  The borrower, RSTEPL, is a special purpose vehicle set up by RPL exclusively to 
develop the project. RPL is a listed group company of the Reliance ADA Group, established to 
develop, construct, and operate power projects in India and abroad. The Reliance ADA Group is 
one  of  India’s  largest  business  conglomerates  with  a  strong  presence  in  the  energy, 
infrastructure, telecommunications, media and entertainment, and financial services sectors. 
 
8.  RPL has a portfolio of 33,440 MW of power generation capacity in various stages of 
development. The operational portfolio is 1,200 MW while 14,460 MW is under construction and 
17,780 MW is under development. Coal-fired power plants (including the three ultra-mega 
power projects—Sasan, Tilaya, and Krishnapatnam) account for 61% of the total portfolio, gas-
fired plants comprise 25%, and hydropower plants represent 14%. The project is its first solar 
thermal energy project. RPL’s renewable energy pipeline for 2012–2017 is in Table 1.

9.  During financial year (FY) 2011, RPL generated revenues of Rs105.48 billion and a net 
profit after tax of Rs7.6 billion on a consolidated basis. As of 31 March 2011, the company had a 
net worth of Rs168.33 billion.3 RPL is 38.41% owned by Reliance Infrastructure Limited (R-Infra) 
and 42.01% by AAA Project Ventures and other Promoter companies—all of which are part of 
the Reliance ADA Group. The remaining 19.48% free float is two-thirds held by retail investors 
and one-third by institutional investors. RPL is listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange and the 
National Stock Exchange.

B.  Development Impact, Outcome, and Outputs 
1.  Impact 
10.  The project is designed to promote sustainable economic growth by diversifying India’s 
energy mix through the addition of renewable energy capacity. In addition, as one of the first 
CSP initiatives, the building of the project will help demonstrate the feasibility of utility-scale 
CSP  projects  in  India  and  the  operational  performance  in  a  location  (Rajasthan)  where 
substantial solar power development is planned during 2012–2017. The project also promotes 
the  efficient  use  of  indigenous  renewable  energy  resources  with  very  limited  emission  of 
pollutants or greenhouse gases.  
 
2.  Outcome 
11.  The project will demonstrate the viability of utility-scale private CSP generation in India 
by generating 242,756 megawatt-hours (MWh)4 of clean energy per annum while delivering 
adequate returns for the private sponsor. 
 
3.  Outputs 
12.  The  successful  implementation  of  the  project  will  result  in  the  construction  and 
commissioning  of  one  of  India’s  first  utility-scale  CSP  plants  and  increase  solar  power 
generation capacity in the country by 100 MW.5 
 
C.  Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations 
1.  Consistency with Strategy 2020 and Country Strategy 
13.  The  project  supports  two  of  the  five  core  operational  areas  of  Strategy  2020—
infrastructure  and  environment.6 The  project  is  aligned  with  the  India  country  partnership 
strategy (CPS), 2009–2012. One of the four strategy pillars of the CPS is to support inclusive 
and environmentally sustainable growth through continued focus on infrastructure development 
and enhanced focus on renewable energy. The project is consistent with one key outcome 
indicator of the CPS, which targets addition of at least 70 MW of solar power generation through 
ADB assistance by 2012.7  
 
2.  Consistency with the Energy Policy and the Asia Solar Energy Initiative 
14.  Under  its  Energy  Policy,  ADB’s  investments  will  focus  on  energy  efficiency  and 
renewable energy projects, as well as expansion of energy access. The policy states that 
support for renewable energy projects will be prioritized and broadened, with an objective of 
creating a framework that makes investing in renewable energy commercially viable. The policy 
envisages that, in the process of facilitating private investments in renewable energy, ADB will

7  ADB. 2009. Country Partnership Strategy: India, 2009–2012. Manila.

4  
assume greater (but thoroughly assessed) risks and act as a catalyst for investments that the 
private sector might not otherwise be willing to make.8 
 
15.  The project is also directly aligned with ADB’s Asia Solar Energy Initiative, which aims to 
(i) facilitate knowledge sharing and transfer for solar power; (ii) help develop, finance, and 
commission 3,000 MW of solar power generation capacity in developing member countries 
(DMCs) by May 2013; and (iii) pilot test innovative financing mechanisms and risk mitigation 
measures specifically for solar power. The initiative seeks to stimulate solar power development 
in DMCs with the goals of (i) increasing economies of scale to reduce costs and improve solar 
energy’s competitiveness within the grid; (ii) exploiting solar radiation resources of selected 
DMCs to serve their fast-growing electricity demand and utilize their greater availability of land 
compared with most developed countries; and (iii) promoting the potential of DMCs to become 
global and regional manufacturing hubs for solar technology goods and equipment. CLFR 
technology employs relatively simple equipment (e.g., structural steel lattices, steel tubes, flat 
mirrors, and drive motors), which can be manufactured locally. This development will generate 
the  potential  for  local  manufacturing  of  such  components,  in  line  with  the  government’s 
objectives under the NSM. In turn, it will reduce the cost of future CSP projects in India. This 
strategy is in line with ADB’s Asia Solar Energy Initiative. 
 
3.  Consistency with ADB Operations 
16.  The project strongly complements ADB’s current initiatives in solar energy in India. In 
April 2011, ADB’s Board of Directors approved the Solar Power Generation Guarantee Facility, 
which will issue partial credit guarantees in an aggregate principal amount of up to $150 million 
(or its equivalent in Indian rupees) in favor of foreign and local commercial financial institutions 
lending  to  solar  power  generation  projects  in  India.  The  facility  will  support  multiple  solar 
generation projects up to a maximum individual capacity of 25 MW under a solar power program 
with the central or state governments. This facility will catalyze commercial lending and private 
investment for smaller solar generation projects, while the proposed project along with the 
Dahanu Solar Power Project9 (approved by ADB’s Board in November 2011) aims to catalyze 
private investment in larger solar generation projects with a capacity greater than 25 MW. The 
lending and guarantee program is complemented by technical assistance provided to the nodal 
ministry for the NSM, and a capacity building and training program for commercial financial 
institutions  to  better  understand  technical  risks  for  solar  power.  This  highlights  ADB’s 
multiproduct  approach  to  promoting  private  investment  in  solar  energy  and  its  ability  to 
customize based on market needs and associated risks. 
 
D.  Project Cost and Financing Plan 
17.  The project is estimated to cost $414.5 million.

E.  Implementation Arrangements 
18.  Table 4 summarizes the implementation arrangements. 
 
Table 4: Summary of Implementation Arrangements 
Aspect  Arrangements
Regulatory framework  The CERC and various SERCs have specified RPOs for electric distribution 
companies. These RPOs require distribution companies to purchase 0.25%–1.00% of 
their total electricity requirements from solar energy sources. Distribution companies 
can use the bundled electricity purchased from NVVN to offset their solar RPOs. 
Prices for solar power sold under the NSM have been competitively bid as a discount 
to the feed-in tariffs established by the CERC for CSP projects. The CERC tariffs are 
evaluated and revised from time to time to take into account capital cost reductions and 
the bid prices for those projects commissioned in early rounds of tendering. 
Operations arrangements    
Revenue structure  RSTEPL has entered into a power purchase agreement with NVVN to sell 100% of the 
output of the project for a period of 25 years at a fixed tariff of Rs11.97 per kWh ($0.24 
per kWh). NVVN, a 100% subsidiary of the NTPC (a majority state-owned entity), has 
been designated as a nodal agency under the NSM for the procurement of solar power. 
NVVN will bundle solar power purchased from the private solar power projects with 
unallocated power from NTPC’s thermal power stations and sell this bundled power to 
the state discoms. 
Implementation period  Construction of the project is expected to be completed in May 2013. The life of the 
power purchase agreement is 25 years from COD. 
Construction arrangements   
Engineering,  RSTEPL has entered into a fixed price turnkey EPC contract with R-Infra for design, 
procurement, and  engineering, procurement and supply, and construction for development of the CSP 
construction   generation plant. The EPC contract includes standard provisions for liquidated 
damages on schedule and performance and is an arm’s-length contract. 
Technology supplier  Under the EPC contract, R-Infra will source the proprietary CLFR technology from 
Areva Solar Inc. USA, a world leader in CLFR technology. Areva Solar Inc. USA is a 
subsidiary of Areva SA France, which is a French public multinational industrial 
conglomerate with a dominant presence in nuclear energy and a growing presence in 
renewable technologies such as CSP, offshore wind power, and biomass.  
Transmission line  The project will share the 30-km 220 kV double circuit transmission line being 
developed by Dahanu Solar Power Private Limited for the 40 MW Dahanu Solar Power 
Project, which is adjacent to the project site. 
Operation and  Areva Renewable Energies India Private Limited, a subsidiary of Areva Renouvelables 
maintenance  SAS (France), will be responsible for O&M of the CSP plant for 5 years from COD.  
Performance monitoring  Key performance indicators will be reported by RSTEPL and monitored by ADB and 
other senior lenders. In addition, during the construction phase, ADB will appoint an 
independent lenders' technical advisor to monitor progress, attend performance testing, 
and verify COD on behalf of the lenders.

F.  Projected Financial and Economic Performance 
19.   The  project  is  financially  viable  and  is  economically  sustainable,  as  the  economic 
internal rate of return is higher than the social discount rate.

III.  THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE 
A.  The Assistance 
20.  The ADB loan of up to $103 million to RSTEPL to finance the construction of the project 
will be provided from ADB’s ordinary capital resources without government guarantee. The ADB 
loan will have a tenor of up to 18 years, including a grace period of up to 24 months, and will be 
repaid semiannually. The ADB loan will carry an interest rate as well as other fees as approved 
by ADB’s investment committee. 
 
B.  Value Added by ADB Assistance 
21.  The proposed transaction merits ADB’s assistance for the following reasons: 
(i)  The ADB assistance will provide long-term, limited recourse financing, which is 
not readily available for large solar power generation projects in India. 
(ii)  The project will use CLFR technology, which has only been commercially proven 
at a smaller scale.  ADB has structured its loan in a manner that will help mitigate 
key technology and operational risks, and thus help demonstrate the viability of 
this technology in developing Asia. The successful operation of a large scale 
CSP project will promote further development of the technology. 
(iii)  The project will promote the efficient use of a relatively untapped, indigenous 
energy resource for electricity generation. Once commissioned, the project will 
be one of the first large-scale concentrating solar power projects in developing 
Asia. 
 
 
C.  Risks 
22.  Technology risk. CLFR is a relatively new CSP technology and has been in commercial 
operations since 2009 at a smaller scale. Over 450 MW of CLFR-based CSP projects are 
currently under development around the world, of which only 16 MW is currently operational. 
The largest CLFR project currently in operation is AREVA Solar USA’s 5 MW plant in California. 
A 30 MW CLFR project is scheduled to be commissioned in Spain in March 2012. Thus, the 
long-term performance of CLFR technology is not yet proven and the project will be subject to 
performance and scale-up risks. However CLFR technology is much less complex than other 
CSP technologies as it does not involve the use of heat transfer fluids, heat exchangers, curved 
mirrors, imported absorption tubes, or complex tracking systems. The performance warranties 
provided by AREVA Solar USA will mitigate this risk. 
 
23.  Off-taker risk. RSTEPL will sell 100% of the output of the project to NVVN, a subsidiary 
of NTPC Limited (a majority state-owned enterprise) at a fixed tariff of Rs11.97 ($0.24) per 
kilowatt-hour for 25 years. NVVN will bundle solar power from this project with unallocated 
thermal power from NTPC and sell it to the state distribution companies through a separate 
power supply agreement. Multiple defaults or payment delays by  various state distribution

7
companies could make it difficult for NVVN to honor its obligations under the power purchase 
agreement with RSTEPL.  
 
CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED 
 
24.  Supply and installation risk. The construction period is expected to be 17 months. All 
major contracts have been executed and construction preparatory works have commenced. 
However, a delay in the commercial operations date will result in loss of revenue to the project. 
The schedule liquidated damages specified in the engineering, procurement, and construction 
(EPC) contract mitigate this risk.  
 
CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED 
 
25.  Operation and maintenance risk. Areva Renewable Energies India Private Limited, a 
100% subsidiary of Areva Renouvelables SAS (France), will be responsible for operation and 
maintenance (O&M) for the first 5 years. O&M for the plant will be primarily limited to ensuring 
adequate cleaning of the mirrors and receivers as well as routine and periodic maintenance of 
the steam turbine. The comprehensive performance guarantees specified in the EPC contract 
and the availability guarantees specified in the O&M contract mean that the residual O&M risk 
beyond 5 years is not considered significant after operations have been normalized. After 5 
years, the O&M activities will likely be undertaken directly by RSTEPL. 
 
CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED 
 
26.  Foreign  exchange  risk. The ADB loan will be denominated in US dollars, but the 
project revenues will be in Indian rupees without any pass through of the foreign exchange risk. 
The loan documentation will specify hedging requirements and/or sponsor support for mitigating 
currency fluctuations.  
 
CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED 
 
27.  Interconnection  risk.  The  project  will  be  connected  to  the  Dechu  substation  of 
Rajasthan Vidyut Prasaran Nigam Limited through the 30 km 220 kV transmission line being 
built by Dahanu Solar Power Private Limited. A delay in construction of the transmission line will 
result in loss of revenue for the project. Construction of the transmission line has commenced 
and is scheduled to be completed by March 2012. The project is scheduled to be completed by 
May 2013. Thus, there is sufficient margin to account for any delay in construction of the 
transmission line. 
 
CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED 
 
IV.  POLICY COMPLIANCE  
A.  Safeguards and Social Dimensions 
28.  In compliance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009), the project is classified 
category  B  for  environment,  category  C  for  involuntary  resettlement,  and  category  C  for 
indigenous peoples. The potential environmental and social impacts of the project have been 
identified and effective measures to avoid, minimize, mitigate, and compensate for the adverse 
impacts are incorporated in the safeguard reports and plans. The institutional capacity and

8  
commitment of RSTEPL to manage the project’s social and environmental impacts are deemed 
adequate. 
 
B.  Anticorruption Policy 
29.  RSTEPL was advised of ADB’s policy of implementing international best practice relating 
to combating corruption, money laundering, and the financing of terrorism. ADB will ensure that 
the  loan  documentation  includes  appropriate  provisions  prohibiting  corruption,  money 
laundering, and the financing of terrorism, and remedies for ADB in the event of noncompliance. 
 
C.  Investment Limitations 
30.  The proposed loan is within the medium term country, industry, group, and single-project 
exposure limits for nonsovereign investments. 
 
D.  Assurances 
31.  Consistent  with  the  Agreement  Establishing  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (the 
Charter),10 the Government of India will be requested to confirm that it has no objection to the 
proposed assistance to RSTEPL. ADB will enter into suitable finance documentation, in form 
and substance satisfactory to ADB, following approval of the proposed assistance by ADB’s 
Board. 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
32.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  recommend  that  the  Board  approve  the  loan  of 
$103,000,000  to  Rajasthan  Sun  Technique  Energy  Private  Limited  for  the  Rajasthan 
Concentrating Solar Power Project in India from ADB’s ordinary capital resources, with such 
terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set forth in this report, and 
as may be reported to the Board. 
 
 
Haruhiko Kuroda 
President  
 
5 March 2012
